title.narrative: Core Support to Ukr. Helsinki Human Rights Union
Core Support to Ukrainian Helsinki Human Rights Union

description.narrative: The overall objective of the intervention is to contribute to the development of a humane society based on respect to human life and dignity, harmonic relations among human, state and nature via maintaining the platform for cooperation among member organizations and other actors of human rights movement, contribute to the practical implementation of the international obligations of Ukraine in the area of human rights.

In 2010, Sida through the Embassy launched a programme of core support to selected Ukrainian NGOs. NGO Helsinki Union, one of the most active human rights organisations in Ukraine, applied to become a candidate. In 2012 the SDA undertook a system-based audit of the NGO. It found it a worthy candidate and recommended that Sida consider pre-core support to prepare for the core support.

description.narrative: This intervention has proved to be extremely timely and relevant at the beginning and throughout its implementation. Working during and after the Revolution of Dignity December 2013-February 2014 and in the midst of the occupation of Crimea followed by the military agression in the East of Ukraine by the Russian Federation, the organization faced fast-evolving challenges emanating from the above-mentiuoned event resulting in mass violations or human rights, documenting war crimes and crimes against humanity duriung trying to respond to, address and mitigate them. The activities of the Ukrainian Helsinki Human Rights Union (UHHRU) has converted into key areas: 1. Establishment of a national network of Public Aid Offices (PAOs), which have rendered lega counseling to vulnerable groups of people affected by the war in the east and occupation of Crimea. Over 40,000 people (54% of men and 46% of women) were sought legal services from PAOs network. 2. Strategic Human Rights Litigation. UHHRU's lawyers have used domestic and international litigation to restore justice, defend the rights of vulnerable groups of popultation, distill, devise, and advocate recommentations to improve (discrimninatory) legislation, etc. Specific examples would include areas: - relating to non-discrimination on ethnical grounds;- on restoration of legal capacity of person in court;- human rights respect and protection in the situation of the armed conflict;- fighting the ban of the Crimean Tatars Mejlis and its recognition as an extremist organization;- protecting victims of domestic violence;- combatting systematic torture of detainees by law enforcement agencies of Ukraine; as well as examples of some successful cases: - nation-wide precedent decision by High Specialized Court of Ukraine for Civil and Criminal Cases:- first-ever precedent victory concerning compensation for housing destroyed during the ATO;- Landmark decision by the Constitutional Court of Ukraine concerning the right to freedom of assembly abolishing the the old norm which allowed religious organizations to conduct gatherings in public places only when approved by local authorities;- Precedent-setting decision on crossing checkpoints with the occupied Crimean peninsula. The analytical part of activities, included documentation of human rights violations in ATO area and occupied Crimea and follow up reporting. Therefore, in the recent period 37 field missions were deployed involving 139 human rights monitors that looked at specific types of violations and a broader human rights environment. Emanating from this, the UHHRU established the Human Rights Abuse Documentation Centre, containing over 4,000 facts of rights violation including instances of deaths. Policy level work comprised making analysis of and drafting of national legislation, Monitoring government institutions for adherence to human rights standards and on compliance with international obligations, preparing analytical products and conducting strategic researches in cooperation with academic institutions. 3. Human Rights Advocacy may boats a few successful accomplishments: - Adoption of a number of laws and regulatory acts to protect rights and freedoms of internally displaced population:Draft law No 2166 “Draft law on amendments to certain legislative acts of Ukraine on strengthening guarantees of observance of rights and freedoms of internally displaced persons”, adopted in January 2016. - Resolution of the Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine No 509 “On registration of IDPs from the temporarily occupied territory of Ukraine and anti-terrorist operation area” (drafted earlier, but amended in June 2016 to bring procedure of IDPs registration in compliance with the Law No 2166). - Discriminatory Regulation No. 79 “Some issues of registration and issuance of certificate on registration of persons who move from temporarily occupied territory of Ukraine or the area of antiterrorist operation” was cancelled in March 2016. - Draft law No 3171 “On amendments to the Civil Procedure Code of Ukraine regarding determination of facts of birth or death in the temporarily occupied territory of Ukraine”, adopted in February 2016. Please refer here for infographic notes (in Ukrainian) on procedures for obtaining birth/death certificates that are prepared by UHHRU’s experts. - Draft Law of Ukraine No 3832 “On amendments to Article 7 of the Law of Ukraine “On ensuring the rights and freedoms and the legal regime on the temporarily occupied territory of Ukraine” adopted in March 2016; And a number of Decrees by the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine to meet the requirements of this law: - Decree of the Ministry dd. May 24, 2016 No 560 “On approval of admission procedure to obtain higher and vocational education for persons residing in the temporarily occupied territory of Ukraine”, registered by the Ministry of Justice in May 2016; - Decree of the Ministry dd. May 19, 2016 No 537 “On approval of certification procedure to validate acquired qualifications, learning results and periods of study in the system of higher education obtained in the temporarily occupied territory of Ukraine after February 20”, registered by the Ministry of Justice in May 2016. - Adoption by the Ukraine’s Parliament of the draft law of Ukraine No 3159 “On Amendments to certain legislative acts of Ukraine on improving the provisions of the judicial protection of foreigners and stateless persons and settlement of certain issues related to countering illegal migration” (May 2016); - Parliamentary initiative – the scandalous draft law No. 3066 “On introducing amendments to the Code of Criminal Procedure of Ukraine on cancellation of bail and mandatory arrest for corrupt officials” was withdrawn by Parliament in February 2016. - UHHRU played a key role in advocating implementation by the governmental agencies of the National Action Plan as enforcement mechanism of the National Human Rights Strategy of Ukraine (see details under “Analytical activities” section). 4.
